item.title: Russia and Ukraine Step Up Attacks Amid Signs That Counteroffensive Is Near
item.description: Russian forces were reportedly moving into defensive positions, as Ukraine’s defense chief said the military was “reaching the finish line” for a major push to reclaim occupied land.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A residential area hit by a Russian strike in Pavlograd, Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: Thousands Flee to Sudan’s Main Seaport, Seeking Ships to Safety
item.description: Port Sudan, on the Red Sea, has been overwhelmed by people fleeing the violence and scrambling to join an evacuation to Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Evacuees on a tugboat on Sunday during a rescue operation from Port Sudan to Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: McCarthy Offers to Host Netanyahu in Washington After Biden Refuses
item.description: The House speaker, Kevin McCarthy, made the informal invitation during a visit to the Israeli Parliament, which came after President Biden had declined to invite the Israeli leader to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, with Kevin McCarthy, the House speaker, center, and the speaker of the Israeli Parliament, Amir Ohana, in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: U.S.-Philippines Alliance Grows With Biden and Marcos Meeting: What to Know
item.description: President Biden met President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of the Philippines at the White House, a sign of strengthening ties between the two countries. Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: President Biden with President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. of the Philippines at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Biden Meets Marcos in Washington Amid Tensions With China
item.description: The Filipino leader’s four-day visit is meant to send a message to China amid conflict over Taiwan and the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden and his advisers have been focusing on cultivating President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. of the Philippines as a regional ally.

item.title: Scotland’s Coronation Day: Charles Souvenirs, Anti-Monarchy Rallies and Shrugs
item.description: The crowning of King Charles III will be a test of sentiment about the monarchy in Scotland, where many supporters of independence see the royals as part of the Britain they want to leave behind.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glasgow has stores selling royal souvenirs, but the city received no applications to close streets for coronation parties, according to the Scottish media.

item.title: In Transylvania, Anyone With $200 Can Live Like a King. (Well, One Specific King.)
item.description: Just don’t expect luxury at the Prince of Wales Guesthouse, where the surrounding forest is the main draw.
item.dc:creator: David Segal
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles’s guesthouse in Valea Zalanului, Romania.

item.title: Anger Over Pensions Law Fuels May Day Protests in France
item.description: Protesters are still hoping to force the government to reverse its decision to raise the legal retirement age to 64 from 62.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Geoffroy Van Der Hasselt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at Place de la Nation in Paris on Monday during May Day demonstrations intensified by anger over a pensions overhaul.

item.title: The Mud Stands in the Way of a Ukrainian Counteroffensive
item.description: The unusually wet ground is one obstacle that the Ukrainian military, for all of its ingenuity, is finding difficult to overcome as it prepares for a counteroffensive against Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier from Ukraine’s 43rd Separate Artillery Brigade jumping down from a Panzerhaubitze, a German-made self-propelled howitzer, in a forest near the front line in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region.

item.title: Woman Charged With 9 Murders in Series of Mysterious Deaths in Thailand
item.description: The police said they found the suspect, 36, with cyanide after the sudden death of a friend with whom she was traveling.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Royal Thai Police, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A photo made available by the Royal Thai Police showing police officers escorting Sararat Rangsiwuthaporn to a criminal court in Bangkok in April.

item.title: A Dutch Quest for Buried Nazi Treasure Comes Up Empty
item.description: The release of a map sketched by a German soldier had touched off a gold rush in a tiny village, but an early-morning excavation failed to solve the mystery.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: A team of experts and archaeologists in the village of Ommeren in the Netherlands on Monday, searching for valuables buried by Nazi soldiers.

item.title: Alireza Akbari, the Iranian Insider and British Spy Executed in Iran
item.description: In January, Iran executed a former senior official who provided Britain with valuable intelligence on Iranian nuclear and military programs over a decade, according to Western intelligence officials.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Alireza Akbari during an interview in Tehran. Iran announced in January that Mr. Akbari had been executed on charges of espionage for Britain.

item.title: Paraguay Voters Elect Conservative Economist as President
item.description: The election of Santiago Peña keeps the right-wing Colorado Party in control of Paraguay, which it has run for all but five of the past 76 years.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Laurence Blair
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Santiago Peña, left, and Colorado Party leader Horacio Cartes celebrating in Asunción, Paraguay after Sunday’s election.

item.title: Pope Reveals He’s Working on Secret ‘Mission’ of Peace in Ukraine
item.description: Francis said he was doing “all that is humanly possible” to help return Ukrainian children taken to Russia and urged Hungary not to slam doors on migrants.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving on Sunday for an open-air Mass in Budapest that drew tens of thousands of Roman Catholic faithful.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The sale of First Republic Bank.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: People walk past the First Republic bank building in downtown San Francisco Monday morning after the bank was taken over by JPMorgan Chase.

item.title: Facial Recognition Powers ‘Automated Apartheid’ in Israel, Report Says
item.description: The Israeli government is using computer vision to monitor Palestinian travel across checkpoints, according to the report.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur
item.category: Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology Co Ltd
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier under a surveillance camera at a checkpoint in Hebron in 2021.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Marcos at the White House
item.description: Also, Russian attacks across Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden and First Lady Dr. Jill Biden greeted Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. President of the Republic of the Philippines and Mrs. Louise Araneta-Marcos, at the White House on Monday.

item.title: In Israel, McCarthy Pledges Continued Support for Ukraine
item.description: The speaker, who warned last year there would be no “blank check” for Ukraine, told a Russian reporter he would continue support to Kyiv against Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Kevin McCarthy, the California Republican who became House speaker in January, addressed Israeli lawmakers in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Says 100,000 Russian Casualties in Ukraine in Past 5 Months
item.description: About half of the dead were mercenaries for the Wagner group, a paramilitary force that recruited heavily from Russian prisons.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned Russian tank in the forest in the village of Ruski Tyshky, north of Kharkiv, Ukraine, in January.

item.title: Keshub Mahindra, Billionaire Indian Industrialist, Dies at 99
item.description: He expanded a family steel and jeep business into an international leviathan, but his career was stained by a conviction in the 1984 Bhopal disaster.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Keshub Mahindra leaving court in Bhopal, India, in 2010, after being convicted of negligence in one of the world’s worst industrial disasters.

item.title: A.I. Is Getting Better at Mind-Reading
item.description: In a recent experiment, researchers used large language models to translate brain activity into words.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang

item.title: Battlefield Update: Russia and Ukraine Both Claim Gains in Bakhmut
item.description: The fight for Bakhmut, the ruined city in eastern Ukraine, has become a focal point of the war as both sides have poured troops into battle and sustained heavy casualties.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a military truck near Bakhmut, Donetsk region, on Sunday.

item.title: The Hard Question of Affirmative Action and Slavery
item.description: If there were an affirmative action program for the descendants of enslaved people, would you consider that to be race-based?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court in October during oral arguments.

item.title: Explosion Derails Freight Train in Bryansk Region of Russia, Local Official Says
item.description: The blast was the latest in a spate of apparent attacks to hit the area bordering Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: Defending press freedom, an eye on China and more on Ukraine’s grain: What to watch for this week.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Juston Jones
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner on Saturday in Washington.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Sudan’s health system on the brink.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ali Shukur/Doctors Without Borders, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Doctors Without Borders shows a hospital in El Fasher in Sudan’s North Darfur region on April 19.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Inside Ukraine’s Trenches
item.description: Also, the potential for civil war in Darfur.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers from Ukraine’s 110th Territorial Defense Brigade taking cover as they fire a mortar round on nearby Russian positions on Monday in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region.

item.title: Freya, the Walrus Killed by Norwegian Officials, Is Immortalized as a Sculpture
item.description: The bronze sculpture depicts the walrus on her side and should remind onlookers about the importance of coexisting, the artist said.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:credit: Annika Byrde/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hans Erik Holm, at right, helped unveil a bronze sculpture in memory of Freya the walrus Saturday in Oslo.

item.title: Gas Shortages Force Cuba to Cancel May Day Parade
item.description: Severe fuel shortages have forced Cuban authorities to cancel the International Workers’ Day parade set for Monday in the capital.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Ed Augustin
item.media:description: Taxis line up at a fuel station in Havana on Tuesday.

item.title: As Hospitals Close and Doctors Flee, Sudan’s Health Care System Is Collapsing
item.description: The medical professionals who remain face meager supplies and harrowing conditions, even setting up field hospitals in living rooms amid the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Fires burning this month near a hospital in Khartoum, Sudan, as seen in a satellite image.

item.title: Blue Check Confusion
item.description: Why Twitter changed its account verifications.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher
item.media:description: The meaning of Twitter’s blue check mark is evolving.

item.title: Ukraine’s Military Says Crimea Blast Was Preparation for Coming Offensive
item.description: Late Sunday, a day after the Crimea blast, explosions rocked Pavlograd in central Ukraine, and air raid sirens sounded across Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Governor of Sevastopol Telegram channel/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A still image taken from a handout video made available by the governor of Sevastopol purporting to show firefighters deployed to extinguish a fire Saturday at an oil depot in Sevastopol, Crimea.

item.title: Mystery Gas Leak in Punjab, India, Leaves at Least 11 Dead
item.description: Officials had not yet been able to identify the gas or the source of the leak in the city of Ludhiana, in Punjab State.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: National Disaster Response Force, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A handout photo showing National Disaster Response Force personnel evacuating people after a gas leak on Sunday in the city of Ludhiana, India.

item.title: Paraguay Picks a New President: What You Need to Know
item.description: The South American nation is deciding between a candidate from the entrenched conservative party and two opposition candidates: an anti-corruption crusader and a far-right firebrand.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Laurence Blair
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officials transporting voting machines in Asunción, the capital of Paraguay, ahead of the election.

item.title: Do People in the U.K. Care About King Charles’s Coronation?
item.description: Images of the new king may be blanketing Britain, but many in the country are more focused on navigating a cost-of-living crisis than celebrating a dysfunctional royal family.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles III and the queen consort, Camilla, attending a ceremony on Thursday at Buckingham Palace in London.

item.title: They Refused to Fight for Russia. The Law Did Not Treat Them Kindly.
item.description: Since Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine, hundreds of Russian men have faced criminal charges for becoming war refuseniks. That has not stopped others from going to unusual lengths to avoid battle.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pro-war sign in Russia. Despite widespread efforts to draft and retain soldiers, there has been a reported increase in AWOL cases.

item.title: If You Don’t Use Your Land, These Marxists May Take It
item.description: The Landless Workers Movement organizes Brazil’s poor to take land from the rich. It is perhaps the largest — and most polarizing — social movement in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Maria Magdalena Arréllaga

item.title: Sudan’s Conflict Ignites Fears of Civil War in Darfur
item.description: The fragile peace that quieted years of genocidal violence in Darfur is at risk again.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of people have fled Sudan in recent weeks, including 1,900 evacuees seen here on a ferry transporting them across the Red Sea from Port Sudan to the King Faisal Naval Base in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, on Saturday.

item.title: Scientist Revisits Data on Raccoon Dogs and Covid, Stressing the Unknowns
item.description: After analyzing genetic data swabbed from a Wuhan market in early 2020, a virologist said it was unclear if animals for sale there had been infected.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: A cleanup crew at the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan, China, in March 2020.

item.title: Ticketmaster Finds Itself in a Royal Mess Over Coronation Concert
item.description: Some British residents said they received misleading emails suggesting they had secured free tickets to the concert for the coronation of King Charles III at Windsor Castle.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Ticketmaster was tasked with issuing 10,000 free tickets to the concert being held on May 7. Some fans feel the site has bungled it.

item.title: ‘Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret’ Arrives
item.description: The books we read when we’re young help shape the adults we become in ways we don’t always grasp.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A Once-Promising Green Energy Technology Hits a Roadblock
item.description: Tidal power turbines operating on the Bay of Fundy in Nova Scotia were suspended after the company running them was unable to get a permit to continue testing.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: David Goldman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A project to create electricity with tidal power has been suspended over its lack of a permit.

item.title: Life in Ukraine’s Trenches: Gearing Up for a Spring Offensive
item.description: With fighting in the eastern Donbas region settling into a bloody stalemate, a patch of the Zaporizhzhia region of southeastern Ukraine could prove to be the war’s next big theater.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: After Warmth From Biden, South Korea’s Yoon Faces a Different Tune at Home
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s foreign policy, aligning his country more closely with Washington and Tokyo, has polarized his country. And critics say he has won little to show for it.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Biden with President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea during the state dinner at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Under the Hollywood Spotlight, Wrexham Is Reborn
item.description: A former industrial hub, Wrexham had long been in decline. Now, it’s reviving as the globally famous star of a reality series about its once forlorn soccer team’s rejuvenation.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural promoting the FX documentary “Welcome to Wrexham” near the home stadium of the soccer team featured in the show.

item.title: Back Then, Baby Galaxies. Next, a Super-Mega Galactic Cluster?
item.description: The Webb telescope has spotted some of the oldest known collections of stars. They may have a very bright future.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, T. Morishita (IPAC), A. Pagan (STScI)
item.media:description: Seven galaxies highlighted in this James Webb Space Telescope image have been confirmed to be at a distance that astronomers refer to as redshift 7.9, which correlates to 650 million years after the Big Bang.

item.title: Large Fire Burns at Crimea Fuel Depot After Suspected Drone Attack
item.description: A Russian-installed local official blamed the blaze on “enemy drones.” Ukraine, which typically maintains a policy of strategic ambiguity about strikes in Crimea, did not claim responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Smoke rising after a strike in Sevastopol in Russian-occupied Crimea on Saturday.

item.title: London’s Other Royals, the ‘Pearlies,’ Keep Alive Cockney Customs
item.description: The Pearly Kings and Queens, known for their button-festooned costumes, preserve a charitable tradition that began in the Victorian era and became a symbol of the city’s working-class culture.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The London Society of Pearly Kings and Queens met in March in Covent Garden to discuss their charity work and upcoming events.

item.title: Deadliest Russian Attack in Months on Ukraine’s Cities Kills at Least 25
item.description: The first widespread barrage on civilian targets in more than a month underscored the vital role of Ukrainian air defenses.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency workers removing the body of a victim from the rubble at the scene of a Russian missile strike on a high-rise residential building in Uman, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: E.U. Extends Tariff Waiver for Ukrainian Grain, Despite Some Protests
item.description: The bloc will provide more than $100 million to farmers in eastern countries where tariff-free Ukrainian grain produced a supply glut and plunging prices.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Ukrainians moving bags of barley inside a grain storage warehouse last July

item.title: Spain Bakes in Summer-Like Heat, and Worries About What Comes Next
item.description: The April temperatures, over 100 degrees Fahrenheit in some places, come on top of a long-running drought that has depleted reservoirs and dried up fields.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Sunbathers on Malvarrosa Beach in Valencia, Spain, on Monday. The country is used to hot weather, just not so early in the year.

item.title: Man Who Has Fathered Hundreds Is Barred From Donating Sperm
item.description: A court in the Netherlands ruled that a man who fathered at least 550 children in the past 16 years had lied to prospective mothers and fertility clinics.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Vials of frozen donor sperm. A prolific sperm donor in the Netherlands has been barred from donating more.

item.title: Mother in Uman Holds Out Hope Her Children Will Be Found After Russian Attack
item.description: A Russian rocket slammed into a nine-story apartment building before dawn in the central Ukrainian city of Uman.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency workers removing the body of a victim on Friday after a Russian missile strike on a high-rise residential building in Uman, Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Begins Overland Evacuation of American Civilians From Sudan
item.description: A bus convoy carrying about 300 people was the first U.S.-organized evacuation effort of Americans other than diplomats since fighting broke out nearly two weeks ago in the northeast African nation.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Eric Schmitt, Edward Wong and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Smoke rising in Khartoum on Friday.

item.title: Pranksters posed as Zelensky in a call with the Federal Reserve chairman.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, participated in a conversation in January with someone who misrepresented himself as the Ukrainian president, the Fed said.

item.title: What I’m Reading: Wives and Muses Edition
item.description: A look at women who inspired great art and literature and what might have been.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Picasso with the painter Françoise Gilot and their children. In her autobiography “Life with Picasso,” Gilot described how Picasso drew on her skills as an artist, demanding that she inspire, critique, and sometimes even paint his own works.

item.title: A More Climate-Resistant Coffee Rises in Africa
item.description: As global warming threatens the two main varieties, coffee growers in Uganda are betting on a type that can stand up to heat, drought and pests.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Khadija Farah for The New York Times
item.media:description: Golooba John, a farmer in Zirobwe, Uganda, lays out Liberica coffee cherries to dry.

item.title: Italian Tourism Campaign With Botticelli’s Venus Faces Backlash
item.description: An initiative featuring a computerized version of Botticelli’s Venus aims to bolster tourism, but it has been roundly mocked in Italy for using stereotypes about the country.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venice in November. The Italian government spent 9 million euros, almost $10 million, on the new tourism campaign.

item.title: War Court Proceedings Stream to Guantánamo From a Secret Chamber in Virginia
item.description: The tribunals were intentionally set up offshore. Now, increasingly, military judges are hearing testimony and arguments from a classified annex.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Guantánamo war court was created to be out of reach of U.S. courts.

item.title: EU Extends Tariff-Free Ukraine Grain Policy, Despite Protests
item.description: Five countries whose farmers have been hurt by the policy, including Poland, will get carve-outs and compensation, under an agreement reached Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Unsold grain in the Kyiv region. Ukraine’s grains will continue to enter the European Union tariff-free for another year despite protest from neighboring countries.

item.title: Australia Eyes a Fraught Pivot from Coal Power to Renewables
item.description: As the country’s oldest power station closed, experts warn that the country needs a clearer strategy to manage its exit from coal power.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Liddell Power Station in Muswellbrook, Australia, on Thursday.
